verses.text: One Sabbath, Jesus went to eat at the house of a leading Pharisee, and they were watching Him carefully.
verses.comment: Jesus' interaction with religious leaders often happens on the Sabbath, highlighting tensions over the interpretation of the law.

verses.text: Right before Him was a man suffering from dropsy.
verses.comment: Dropsy refers to abnormal swelling due to fluid; Jesus' miracles frequently involve restoring bodily wholeness as a sign of His authority and compassion.

verses.text: Jesus responded to the lawyers and Pharisees, saying, "Is it lawful to heal on the Sabbath, or not?"
verses.comment: Christ is testing their understanding of mercy versus a narrow legalism regarding Sabbath observance.

verses.text: But they remained silent. So He took the man, healed him, and sent him away.
verses.comment: Their silence signifies their inability to oppose Jesus' authority or to respond compassionately.

verses.text: Then He said to them, "Which of you, if his son or his ox falls into a well on a Sabbath day, will not immediately pull him out?"
verses.comment: Jesus appeals to natural law and compassion, drawing a parallel between human need and acts of mercy, showing the law is fulfilled by love (see Gal. 5:14).

verses.text: They couldn't reply to these things.
verses.comment: Their inability to answer exposes the poverty of their legalism in the face of Christ's divine wisdom.

verses.text: Now He told a parable to the invited guests, noticing how they chose the places of honor, saying to them:
verses.comment: Jesus often uses table fellowship to teach about humility and God's kingdom.

verses.text: "When you are invited by someone to a wedding feast, do not sit in the place of honor, in case someone more distinguished than you has been invited.
verses.comment: Echoes Old Testament wisdom (Prov. 25:6-7), teaching humility as a fundamental virtue.

verses.text: Then the one who invited you both will come and say to you, ‘Give your place to this person,’ and then with shame you will begin to take the lowest place.
verses.comment: A reversal of worldly expectations, reflecting the 'last shall be first' theme (Matt. 20:16).

verses.text: But when you are invited, go and sit in the lowest place, so that when your host comes, he may say to you, ‘Friend, move up higher.’ Then you will be honored in the presence of all who sit at the table with you.
verses.comment: God exalts the humble. The banquet image prefigures the heavenly wedding feast (Rev. 19:9).

verses.text: For everyone who exalts himself will be humbled, and he who humbles himself will be exalted."
verses.comment: A central teaching of Jesus on humility, echoed throughout Scripture (see also Phil. 2:5-11).

verses.text: He also said to the one who had invited Him, "When you give a lunch or a dinner, do not invite your friends, your brothers, or your relatives or rich neighbors, in case they might invite you in return, and you would be repaid.
verses.comment: True charity is selfless, mirroring God's unmerited favor towards us.

verses.text: But when you give a feast, invite the poor, the crippled, the lame, and the blind.
verses.comment: The call to serve the marginalized reflects Jesus’ heart for the poor and lowly, and the Church’s long tradition of charity.

verses.text: And you will be blessed, because they cannot repay you. You will be repaid at the resurrection of the righteous."
verses.comment: Points to the reality of final resurrection and reward for acts of mercy, referencing eschatological hope.

verses.text: When one of those reclining at the table with Him heard this, he said to Jesus, "Blessed is everyone who will eat bread in the kingdom of God!"
verses.comment: Echoes Old Testament anticipation of God’s end-time feast with His people.

verses.text: But He said to him, "A certain man gave a great banquet and invited many.
verses.comment: The parable setting continues Jesus' favorite image for the messianic kingdom.

verses.text: At the time for the banquet, he sent his servant to say to those who had been invited, ‘Come, for everything is now ready.’
verses.comment: The urgency of the invitation mirrors God's call to accept salvation in the fullness of time (Gal. 4:4).

verses.text: But they all alike began to make excuses. The first said to him, ‘I have bought a field, and I must go out and see it. Please have me excused.’
verses.comment: Excuses represent preoccupation with worldly affairs over eternal matters.

verses.text: Another said, ‘I have bought five yoke of oxen, and I am going to test them. Please have me excused.’
verses.comment: Continuing the theme of temporal concerns impeding response to God's invitation.

verses.text: Another said, ‘I have married a wife, and therefore I cannot come.’
verses.comment: Cultural obligations sometimes stood in tension with the call of God's kingdom, requiring discernment of priorities (see Matt. 10:37).

verses.text: So the servant came and reported these things to his master. Then the master of the house became angry and said to his servant, ‘Go out quickly into the streets and lanes of the city, and bring in the poor, crippled, blind, and lame.’
verses.comment: The invitation is extended to the outcasts, demonstrating God's mercy and inclusive call to the kingdom.

verses.text: And the servant said, ‘Sir, what you commanded has been done, and there is still room.’
verses.comment: The kingdom's abundance is such that there is always room for more to respond to the call of grace.

verses.text: And the master said to the servant, ‘Go out to the highways and hedges and compel them to come in, so that my house may be filled.’
verses.comment: The word 'compel' has sacramental overtones, hinting at a strong and effective invitation (see Matt. 22:9-10).

verses.text: For I tell you, none of those men who were invited shall taste my banquet."
verses.comment: There are real consequences to rejecting God’s invitation. The house imagery represents the gathered people of God.

verses.text: Now great crowds were traveling with Him, and He turned and said to them:
verses.comment: A shift: Jesus moves from teaching at a table to addressing the large crowds, raising the demands of discipleship.

verses.text: "If anyone comes to Me and does not hate his own father and mother, wife and children, brothers and sisters, yes, and even his own life, he cannot be My disciple.
verses.comment: 'Hate' is a Semitic exaggeration for 'love less by comparison.' Jesus demands undivided loyalty, indicating His unique authority (cf. Deut. 6:5).

verses.text: Whoever does not carry his own cross and come after Me cannot be My disciple.
verses.comment: Taking up the cross is a call to self-sacrifice and willingness to follow Christ, hinting at the redemptive suffering that is a hallmark of following Jesus.

verses.text: "For which of you, wanting to build a tower, does not first sit down and count the cost, to see if he has enough to finish it?
verses.comment: Discipleship requires serious commitment, not shallow enthusiasm.

verses.text: Otherwise, after he has laid a foundation and cannot finish, all who see it will mock him,
verses.comment: A warning against superficial or half-hearted commitment to Christ.

verses.text: saying, ‘This man began to build and was not able to finish.’
verses.comment: Relationship with Christ is not a temporary project but calls for perseverance (see Phil. 1:6).

verses.text: "Or what king, going out to confront another king in war, will not sit down and consider whether he is able with ten thousand to meet the one coming against him with twenty thousand?
verses.comment: Another example illustrating thoughtful consideration in following Christ.

verses.text: And if not, while the other is still far away, he sends a delegation and asks for terms of peace.
verses.comment: Planning and counting the cost reinforces the seriousness and realism demanded in discipleship.

verses.text: So therefore, any one of you who does not renounce all that he has cannot be My disciple.
verses.comment: Total surrender marks true discipleship—echoing Christ’s call to give up earthly attachments for eternal treasure.

verses.text: "Salt is good, but if salt loses its taste, how will it be made salty again?
verses.comment: Salt was used for preserving and flavoring; a disciple without commitment loses the ability to impact the world.

verses.text: It is fit neither for the soil nor for the manure pile; it is thrown away. He who has ears to hear, let him hear."
verses.comment: A call for spiritual attentiveness, making clear that following Christ requires faithfulness and perseverance—qualities deeply linked to the Church’s call to holiness and unity across the ages.
